name: Yang–Mills existence and mass gap
rephrased: Prove that a consistent quantum theory of gauge fields exists with particles having a minimum mass (mass gap) for certain types of symmetry groups (compact simple gauge groups).
implication_form: If G is a compact simple gauge group, then a non-trivial quantum Yang-Mills theory with a mass gap exists on R⁴.
posed_by: Chen Ning Yang and Robert Mills
explained: The Yang–Mills existence and mass gap problem requires proving the existence of a non-trivial quantum Yang–Mills theory on four-dimensional Euclidean space (R⁴) for any compact, simple gauge group G, along with the existence of a mass gap (i.e., a positive lower bound on the masses of all particles in the spectrum). This means demonstrating a mathematically rigorous foundation for the quantum field theories that describe the strong nuclear force, which currently rely on heuristic methods and lack a complete proof of existence and the explanation for the mass gap, which is crucial for understanding why these forces have a short range.
